title: 107_s3096
content: The "Ballistics, Law Assistance, and Safety Technology Act" or the "BLAST Act" aims to increase public safety by assisting law enforcement in solving gun-related crimes through ballistics technology. It requires ballistics testing of all new firearms for sale and those in custody of Federal agencies to aid in identifying firearms used in crimes. Additionally, it adds ballistics testing to existing firearms enforcement programs. SEC. 3. DEFINITION OF BALLISTICS. The term 'ballistics' means a comparative analysis of fired bullets and cartridge casings to identify the firearm from which they were discharged. Amendment to Section 923 of title 18, United States Code requires licensed manufacturers or importers to test fire firearms, prepare ballistics images, store records in a database, and store fired bullet and cartridge casings as specified by the Secretary. The Attorney General and the Secretary will assist in compliance. No civil liability except for civil penalties. Firearm manufacturers and importers must comply with regulations by acquiring ballistics equipment, hiring personnel for database maintenance, providing education on ballistics, coordinating with law enforcement agencies, and taking necessary steps for effective ballistics testing. The Attorney General and the Secretary will establish a computer system for law enforcement agencies to access ballistics information promptly. The Attorney General and the Secretary will establish a computer system for law enforcement agencies to access ballistics records promptly. They will also encourage training for ballistics examiners. Additionally, they are required to submit an annual report to Congress on the impact of this section, including the use of ballistics records in criminal investigations and the accessibility of such records across jurisdictions. The Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury are authorized to appropriate funds for ballistics equipment, testing sites, personnel salaries, and research. Mandatory ballistics testing of firearms by the Secretary and the Attorney General is required. The effective date of these provisions will be determined by the Attorney General and the Secretary of the Treasury in consultation with the Board of the National. The Attorney General and the Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the National Integrated Ballistics Information Network, must certify the interoperability of ballistics systems for mandatory testing of new firearms. The effective dates for the provisions are specified in the legislation. SEC. 5. PRIVACY RIGHTS OF LAW ABIDING CITIZENS. Ballistics information of individual guns may not be used for prosecutorial purposes unless law enforcement officials have a reasonable belief that a crime has been committed and that ballistics information would assist in the investigation.
